Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: A noise complaint has circulated on the floor, and a face-to-face meeting in the lobby calls for extra courtesy.
Situation2: They fill a high-risk chemotherapy prescription where even a small error could have severe consequences for the patient.
Story: I was on my way to the pharmacy, rehearsing the steps for filling a complex chemotherapy prescription. Every detail mattered—one slip could mean disaster for the patient. My mind was already running through dosage calculations when I stepped into the lobby and saw Mrs. Kim, my neighbor from down the hall. She smiled, but I could sense tension; the noise complaint had everyone on edge. I knew I should be extra friendly, maybe even offer a few reassuring words to smooth things over. But my thoughts kept drifting back to the prescription waiting for me. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in—my neighbors expected warmth and civility, while my profession demanded unwavering focus and precision. As Mrs. Kim approached, I could feel my heart race, torn between stopping to chat and hurrying to the pharmacy to double-check every step of the medication process.
